title: Republican infighting at full throttle
content:
GOP leadership has spent weeks twisting arms to get dozens of lawmakers — even some subcommittee chairs — to pony up to the campaign arm , a basic annual obligation of party loyalty .
The party is warring over funding for disease research , bickering over an education bill and deeply divided on the possible renewal of the Export-Import Bank , an object of scorn among the far right . On Wednesday evening , House Republican leaders had to work the floor feverishly to pass the education measure , clearing it with no margin for error .
The bipartisan Kumbaya that swept Washington after Congress cleared a trade package last month has completely dissipated . And Republicans are clashing in private — and , at times , openly — over their entire agenda .
The broad disagreement on so many fronts lately is striking .
Congress is almost certain , again , to fail to come to a timely agreement on a long-term highway bill . Republican leaders had to abruptly pull the emergency brake on a sweeping reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration , amid a tiff about privatizing air traffic controllers .
As if all that wasn ’ t enough , a showdown over government funding is fast approaching . The GOP-controlled Senate and House are at loggerheads , and if they can ’ t broker a deal with Democrats , the government will shut down at the end of September . A deadline to raise the debt ceiling looms late this year or possibly in early 2016 .
House GOP leaders face a collection of conservatives once again feeling emboldened by their ability to stifle the leadership ’ s agenda without retribution . The latest , most glaring example : Rep. Mark Meadows ( R-N.C. ) , who lost but then regained his chairmanship in the course of a few days , was greeted by raucous applause from constituents in his district for taking on the Washington establishment .
The House Freedom Caucus — several dozen conservatives who take pride in bucking Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) — said it grew by three members just this week . Former top-ranking Republicans — like Rep. Darrell Issa of California — have expressed interest in joining .
“ I don ’ t think that ’ s something anyone comments on , either way , ” Issa said in a brief interview , noting he ’ s a member of other caucuses .
Top committee chairmen are now realizing the ragtag group of conservatives deserves attention . Rep. Joe Pitts ( R-Pa. ) , who chairs a key health care subcommittee , met with the group ’ s leadership to drum up support for a bill to increase funding for research to find cures for diseases . The bill is sure to pass , but faces stiff resistance within the Freedom Caucus who have taken issue with the way the program is funded .
Leaders have also had to wrangle with several GOP lawmakers over “ dues ” they ’ re expected to pay to the National Republican Congressional Committee .
While the party committee relies on donors to underwrite most of their political activities — primarily to help reelect incumbent Republicans — money from lawmakers is another important source of funding . But top Republicans , chiefly Missouri Rep. Ann Wagner , were forced to make a last-minute push to collect dues from tardy lawmakers .
The reasons for not donating to the NRCC vary , but they do represent a measure of discord within the House Republican Conference . Many members in the Freedom Caucus forgo paying their full dues , including Rep. Scott Garrett ( R-N.J. ) , who chairs a prized Financial Services subcommittee .
All of this acrimony has led some top Republican officials to wonder whether they ’ ll ever be able to get things in line .
House GOP leaders have seen this play before . Time and again since 2010 , their attempts at legislating have devolved into chaos . The government has shut down , Congress nearly breached the nation ’ s credit limit , the Department of Homeland Security almost closed , there have been two challenges to Boehner ’ s speakership and a majority leader was toppled by conservative forces .
But Boehner , House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and House Majority Whip Steve Scalise ( R-La . ) hoped to have the place under control by now . And it ’ s clear that over the next few months , they ’ ll face stiff challenges that will set the tone for the future of each leader ’ s political career .
Nowhere is this drama more obvious than the internal tussle over renewing highway funding and the Export-Import Bank ’ s charter . Boehner has promised to allow House Financial Services Chairman Jeb Hensarling ( R-Texas ) an opportunity to defeat any attempt to renew the bank ’ s charter — even if it comes as part of a highway bill . But Hensarling and his allies have privately pushed leadership to ignore any legislation to the floor that extends the charter . Meanwhile , Ex-Im supporters — like Rep. Stephen Fincher ( R-Tenn. ) — are actively working to defeat Hensarling on the issue .
“ I think at the end of the day , level heads will prevail and we can get this done , ” Fincher said . “ This is jobs , jobs , jobs . And transportation is a big deal , too . Hopefully , members won ’ t take a narrow position and vote against transportation because of a jobs bill , and that ’ s what the Ex-Im bank is . ”
This week , Republicans had to beat back small uprisings on two fronts . First , conservatives were concerned that a long-stalled education bill didn ’ t meet conservative muster , because it did not include language that would block grant federal funds to individual states . The measure passed Wednesday evening with no votes to spare . The disease research bill also encountered vocal criticism , though it ’ s expected to pass handily with Democratic support ..
“ It ’ s certainly not the way I would have funded it , but I think the policy is good enough , but it ’ s OK , ” said Rep. Bill Flores of Texas , chairman of the conservative Republican Study Committee .
House Republican leaders argue they ’ ve successfully weathered the first half of the year and are ready for the fights ahead . But they also acknowledge they have been dinged up . House Oversight and Government Reform Chairman Jason Chaffetz ( R-Utah ) reversed a decision to punish Meadows — a thorn in the side of leadership — which has emboldened the opposition to leadership .
The upcoming legislative fights will be a major test for leadership , not the least the FAA reauthorization . House Transportation and Infrastructure Chairman Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania has been working on the bill —which privatizes the air traffic control system — for years . As of last week , Shuster ’ s aides were planning on briefing committee members ’ staff on the legislation Monday afternoon . The meeting was abruptly canceled , after McCarthy made the decision that July was far too busy for Shuster ’ s bill .
“ There is still a lot to be worked out , ” said Missouri Republican Rep. Sam Graves , a close ally of the private aviation industry . “ There are still a lot of questions to be answered . How it is going to affect various aspects of aviation ? How we ’ re going to pay for it ? How much money is it going to save — we may not have to pay anything if we save a enough money . There are still a lot of things that need to be considered and figured out . ”
Graves added , “ July is just a disaster . … I think it will be September , probably . ”
